awd_abstract_narration:
Thanks to major advances in laser technology, there is an ongoing interest in the study of light interacting with matter, in particular for intense laser beams propagating long distances in the atmosphere. Laser pulses exceeding tens of gigawatts power can be used in many applications including remote sensing through Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR), lightning and weather control and free-space optics communication. Current research on free space optical communications (FSO), both classical and quantum, is intended to facilitate exchange of information within a network of satellites, between the Earth and satellites and between the Earth and drones. This and other aspects to be studied, such as diffraction control, are in line with topics within Quantum Leap, one of the NSF's 10 Big Ideas. In searching for optimal performance, it is critical to seek better understanding of a range of spatial and temporal effects that take place while light interacts with molecules in the atmosphere. For this, proper mathematical and numerical modeling assist experimentalists to for example consider novel modes of propagation (optical filaments versus vortex filaments) and the possible coexistence of multi- color (multi-frequency) filaments. Research performed under this award will have a strong synergy with experimental groups, enriching the interdisciplinary nature of the project and enhancing the learning experience of applied mathematics graduate students to be trained in a multifaceted approach.

Under the general theme of light matter interactions, the PI and students will investigate spatiotemporal dynamics of light propagation in nonlinear media. The research addresses well defined questions related to the characterization of highly nonlinear optical modes of different types  (filament modes, vortex modes and combinations) in three different media: air (Kerr media), carrying two frequencies (typically ultraviolet and infrared), nonlinear crystals (quadratic media) where little is known on the theory of filament formation at phase mismatch  and on the formation of filaments in discrete/continuum nonlinear media with fractional diffraction and quadratic dispersion. The first two topics represent significant extensions of ongoing research in filament science, based either on recent experimental observations or potential new experiments on which the PI has been and will be directly involved. By the nature and objectives of the research, the effort supported by this award will benefit from continuing interactions with several experimental teams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The study of interaction between light and matter continues to be an imponrtant research field in nonlinear science. Better understanding and modeling of the propagation of an intense laser in the atmosphere or the propagation of intense light in a crystal continues to advance or parallel experimental realizations, including the propagation of a light filament for kilometer ranges in air. Models. like those considered in this project  can  support  newly discovered phenomena such as the "cleaning" (removal of speckles) of a light filament (see figure). Furthermore, modern photonics technologies present unique opportunities to manipulate light properties for specific applications. This project advanced understanding in nonlinear photonics on dircrete systems (optical waveguide arrays) and photonics in a chip, where the particular architectures can engineer temporal dispersion or spatial diffraction. On this, our theoretical studies provided understanding of the properties of a novel type of optical pulses known as quartic solitons (see figure). These pulses can be very energetic and of short duration.While these pulses are still too large compared to attosecond scales, the recent award of the 2023 Nobel prize in Physics highlights the importance of experimentally generating ultrashort (atto-second)pulses. 

As it relates to engineering diffraction, a current topic of research under the title "fractional nonlinear optics" offers an intriguing view of fractional diffraction. In the case of light propagating in an array of waveguides, fractionality translates into long-range interactions of the light propagating along different waveguides. Our studies suggest the emergence of coherent structures with a localized imprint, even as they propagate in such a way that the interaction beteeen them is nonlocal (see figure).  While the models are relatively new and the potential applications are yet to be realized, this is an emerging field and deliverables from this work have propelled further studies.

Contributions in the related fresearch field known as topological photonics include studies on mobility or transport of energy concentrated in localized modes of light where by proper modulation of the guiding waveguide arrays along the direction of propagation allows "hopping" of light across the array.

This scientific effort had an international flavor. The team supported by the grant collaborated with researchers in France, Italy and the UK. Finally, the project provided a forum to train young scholars. By the end of the project, a student completed his PhD (he is now working in the world of finance), and a  young postdoctoral scholar who was part of the team, is now a faculty at the West Point Academy. Beyond these two young scholars, the full team that contributed to this project, though not directly funded by it, included another NSF supported sholar (a student recipient of an NSF graduate fellowship; a graduate student and a postdoctoral fellow supported by an  NSF Research Training Group (RTG) award lead bt the same PI).
